ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a ton about writing techniques, voice, tone, rhetorical strategies, and how writers write. I grew a lot as a writer and as a reader, and found the workshop process of the class really well-suited to improvement and learning.
-tendencies/flaws in my own writing, and how to edit
I learned how to write creatively and story tell efficiently.
Writing skills.
I learned more about different styles of writing and had the opportunity to get a lot of practice with creative non-fiction that I hadn't had before.
It helped me find a writing style and voice that were my own by feeling out different techniques from other authors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I love pretty much everything about this course. No complaints. Great teacher, great essays, great feedback, great prompts. I learned kind of a lot and like it kind of a lot.

weaknesses: engagement with other students; sometimes discussion lagged
strengths: getting feedback! and process of reworking things
I think this course could be improved by cutting one essay and having the final paper be a 3rd revision.
Great syllabus/reading lists; really enjoyed workshops
Strong discussion.

The course is a great opportunity to have a lot of practice writing in different styles. I do wish there were slightly more structured conversations about each writing style specifically/more concrete information about each unit.

Strengths: if you like to read or write at all, its a fun class! Well-designed with a wide range of engaging essays. Craigs feedback was really great and very helpful.
Weaknesses: Nothing, really.

The course readings are amazing and the essay prompts are too. The only thing I would change is to have less intensive workshops (where the whole class workshops two or three essays), and have all the essays have student feedback through a collaborative system.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Love, love, love this course. Take it if you want to improve your writing, personal or otherwise. Also isn't a super hard class and you get a lot out of it.
yes; a really good foundational class I think
Absolutely. The course has made me a much better writer.
Yes, absolutely - I think students from a range of academic backgrounds would benefit from the course (a lot of personal reflection, critical thinking, skill development w/r/t writing)
Yes. Good course.
If you're looking to improve your writing and have some structured practice, then yes this is a great course for that.
Yes!! Especially if Craig teaches it. In Yales world of academic writing, it was really fun to have the chance to get creative and write in new styles.
I would definitely recommend it if you like writing a lot, don't take it for the writing credit.
